text:
Is there a function in some interpolation package maybe that does something like this except faster? (given tt and tt0 are sorted)
```map(x->findmin(abs.(x .- tt0))[2], tt)```

elements.text: Is there a function in some interpolation package maybe that does something like this except faster? (given tt and tt0 are sorted)

text:
here you go buddy!
```oo = let
    ro = zeros(Int, length(tt))
    xi = 1
    for ii in 1:length(tt)
        t = tt[ii]
        v = tt0[xi]
        nv = xi < length(tt0) ? tt0[xi+1] : typemax(Int)
        while !((t-v) > 0 && (t-nv) < 0)
            xi = xi + 1
            v = tt0[xi]
            nv = xi < length(tt0) ? tt0[xi+1] : typemax(Int)
        end
    ro[ii] = abs(t-v) < abs(t-nv) ? xi : xi+1
    end
ro
end```

elements.text:
oo = let
    ro = zeros(Int, length(tt))
    xi = 1
    for ii in 1:length(tt)
        t = tt[ii]
        v = tt0[xi]
        nv = xi < length(tt0) ? tt0[xi+1] : typemax(Int)
        while !((t-v) > 0 && (t-nv) < 0)
            xi = xi + 1
            v = tt0[xi]
            nv = xi < length(tt0) ? tt0[xi+1] : typemax(Int)
        end
    ro[ii] = abs(t-v) < abs(t-nv) ? xi : xi+1
    end
ro
end

text: I'm not your code-reviewer so I hope this doesn't come off as an imposition-- you may not even be writing that for anybody, either-- but that snippet could do with some comments and verbosification of variable names.
